clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Metformin on Reducing Lupus Flares
clinical_study.official_title: A Multicenter, Randomised, Double-blind Placebo Controlled Trial on the Efficacy and Safety of add-on Metformin to Conventional Immunosuppressants in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a multicenter, randomised, double-blind placebo controlled trial on the efficacy and safety of add-on metformin to conventional immunosuppressants in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
The purpose of this study is to evaluate: 1) the effect of metformin on reducing disease flares; 2) the influence of metformin on corticosteroid sparing effect; 3) the influence of metformin on body mass index (BMI); 4) the safety of metformin.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: numbers of participants who remained at risk of flares at each visit
primary_outcome.description: the effect of metformin on reducing disease flares

secondary_outcome.measure: changes in prednisone dose from baseline at each visit
secondary_outcome.description: the influence of metformin on corticosteroid sparing effect

secondary_outcome.measure: changes in BMI from baseline at each visit
secondary_outcome.description: the influence of metformin on BMI

secondary_outcome.measure: number of participants with treatment-related adverse events

arm_group.description: Eligible patients for clinical trial were randomized in a 1:1 ratio to metformin/placebo add-on. Subjects randomized to metformin will receive a target dose of 500 mg three times daily. Investigators were allowed to adjust the dose according to the patients' tolerance.
